elements.content: The solid-state structure of a potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate cluster, K6[MeSn(O)CO3]6·14H2O (2), a significant intermediate in the synthesis of methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n (1), was investigated by X-ray crystallography. The hexameric methylstannoxyl carbonate ion [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6− features the common drum-type structure observed for many neutral organostannoxyl carboxylates [RSn(O)CO2R′]6 (R, R′ = alkyl, aryl). Compounds 1 and 2 were also studied by 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text: The solid-state structure of a potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate cluster, K6[MeSn(O)CO3]6⋅14H2O (2), a significant intermediate in the synthesis of methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1), was investigated by X-ray crystallography. The hexameric methylstannoxyl carbonate ion [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6- features the common drum-type structure observed for many neutral organostannoxyl carboxylates [RSn(O)CO2R']6 (R, R' = alkyl, aryl). Compounds 1 and 2 were also studied by 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: The hexameric potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate cluster K6[MeSn(O)CO3]6·14H2O (2) is a significant intermediate in the synthesis of methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n (1) and features a common drum-type structure known for many neutral organostannoxyl carboxylates [RSn(O)CO2R′]6 (R, R′ = alkyl, aryl). The solid-state structures of 1 and 2 were investigated by 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy and that of 2 also by X-ray crystallography.
elements.clean_text: The hexameric potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate cluster K6[MeSn(O)CO3]6⋅14H2O (2) is a significant intermediate in the synthesis of methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1) and features a common drum-type structure known for many neutral organostannoxyl carboxylates [RSn(O)CO2R']6 (R, R' = alkyl, aryl). The solid-state structures of 1 and 2 were investigated by 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy and that of 2 also by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: Methylstannonic acid, [MeSn(O)OH] n (1), was obtained more than 120 years ago by the simple reaction of SnCl2 with methyl iodide and aqueous KOH (Scheme ). Under these basic reaction conditions, [MeSn(O)OH] n (1) is soluble in water and exists as oligomeric methylstannoxyl anions containing hexacoordinated tin atoms, which were investigated by 119Sn NMR spectroscopy. The isolation of [MeSn(O)OH] n (1) from these basic solutions makes use of carbon dioxide, which decreases the pH value and leads to the formation of a potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate with the empirical formula K[MeSn(O)CO3]·H2O as a crystalline intermediate, but with hitherto unknown structure. Treatment of this intermediate with hot water releases the amorphous polymeric methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n (1). The recent interest in the molecular organostannonic acids cis-[(Me3Si)3CSn(O)OH]3, trans-[(2,6-Mes2C6H3Sn(O)OH]3, [(2,4,6-i-Pr3C6H2Sn(O)OH]6, and [2,6-(Me2NCH2)2C6H3Sn(O)OH]6 as well as the carbon dioxide fixation and activation ability of organotin oxides and related species prompted a structural investigation of the crystalline potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate by X-ray crystallography and 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text: Methylstannonic acid, [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1), was obtained more than 120 years ago by the simple reaction of SnCl2 with methyl iodide and aqueous KOH (Scheme ).   Under these basic reaction conditions, [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1) is soluble in water and exists as oligomeric methylstannoxyl anions containing hexacoordinated tin atoms, which were investigated by 119Sn NMR spectroscopy.   The isolation of [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1) from these basic solutions makes use of carbon dioxide, which decreases the pH value and leads to the formation of a potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate with the empirical formula K[MeSn(O)CO3]⋅H2O as a crystalline intermediate, but with hitherto unknown structure.   Treatment of this intermediate with hot water releases the amorphous polymeric methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1).   The recent interest in the molecular organostannonic acids cis-[(Me3Si)3CSn(O)OH]3,   trans-[(2,6-Mes2C6H3Sn(O)OH]3,   [(2,4,6-i-Pr3C6H2Sn(O)OH]6,   and [2,6-(Me2NCH2)2C6H3Sn(O)OH]6    as well as the carbon dioxide fixation and activation ability of organotin oxides and related species   prompted a structural investigation of the crystalline potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate by X-ray crystallography and 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="om-2009-00797a_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

A representative specimen of the potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate turned out to have the exact composition K6[MeSn(O)CO3]6·14 H2O (2) and contains hydrated potassium cations and [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6− anions. The molecular structure of the [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6− ion comprises a prismatic or so-called hexameric drum structure and is shown in Figure . Selected bond parameters are collected in the figure caption. The hexameric drum is a commonly found structural motif in neutral organostannoxyl carboxylates [RSn(O)CO2R′]6 (R, R′ = alkyl, aryl). The faces of the drum may be described as two Sn3O3 six-membered rings that are linked in two complementary ways. Each oxygen atom of each ring connects to a tin atom of the second ring, of opposite orientation, leading to six μ3-oxo atoms. The girth of the drum may be considered as six Sn2O2 four-membered rings arranged so as to form a tube. Six bidentate bridging carbonate ions diagonally span the Sn2O2 four-membered rings. The methyl groups are oriented above and below the faces of the drum. The centrosymmetric anion contains three crystallographically independent hexacoordinated Sn atoms and carbonate ions. Consistently, the 119Sn MAS NMR spectrum of 2 shows three signals at δiso = −474, −481, and −486 having approximately equal intensities. The 13C MAS NMR spectrum shows two sets of three signals at δiso = 164.2, 162.2, and 160.7 as well as 8.0, 5.7, and 5.2, which were assigned to the crystallographically independent carbonate ions and methyl groups. The spatial arrangement of the tin atoms is distorted octahedral and defined by O5C-donor sets. The Sn−μ3-O bond lengths (Sn−O bonds within the hexameric cage) cover a range from 2.079(7) to 2.121(7) Å (average 2.102(7) Å), while the Sn−μ2-O bond lengths (related to the bidentate carbonate ions) are slightly longer, ranging from 2.106(7) to 2.167(8) Å (average 2.129(9) Å). The spatial arrangement of the three independent carbonate ions is rather unsymmetric. Those oxygen atoms involved in coordination to the tin atoms show rather long C−O bond lengths, ranging from 1.28(2) to 1.32(2) Å, while the remaining C−O bond lengths are between 1.24(2) and 1.25(1) Å. The latter oxygen atoms are involved in coordination to the potassium ions, whose coordination sphere is completed by five or six water molecules, with K−O distances varying between 2.73(1) and 3.16(1) Å. Overall, the hydrated potassium ions fill the voids between the hexameric methylstannoxyl carbonate ions [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6− in the crystal lattice.
elements.clean_text: A representative specimen of the potassium methylstannoxyl carbonate   turned out to have the exact composition K6[MeSn(O)CO3]6⋅14 H2O (2) and contains hydrated potassium cations and [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6- anions. The molecular structure of the [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6- ion comprises a prismatic or so-called hexameric drum structure and is shown in Figure . Selected bond parameters are collected in the figure caption. The hexameric drum is a commonly found structural motif in neutral organostannoxyl carboxylates [RSn(O)CO2R']6 (R, R' = alkyl, aryl).   The faces of the drum may be described as two Sn3O3 six-membered rings that are linked in two complementary ways. Each oxygen atom of each ring connects to a tin atom of the second ring, of opposite orientation, leading to six μ3-oxo atoms. The girth of the drum may be considered as six Sn2O2 four-membered rings arranged so as to form a tube. Six bidentate bridging carbonate ions diagonally span the Sn2O2 four-membered rings. The methyl groups are oriented above and below the faces of the drum. The centrosymmetric anion contains three crystallographically independent hexacoordinated Sn atoms and carbonate ions. Consistently, the 119Sn MAS NMR spectrum of 2 shows three signals at δiso = -474, -481, and -486 having approximately equal intensities. The 13C MAS NMR spectrum shows two sets of three signals at δiso = 164.2, 162.2, and 160.7 as well as 8.0, 5.7, and 5.2, which were assigned to the crystallographically independent carbonate ions and methyl groups. The spatial arrangement of the tin atoms is distorted octahedral and defined by O5C-donor sets. The Sn-μ3-O bond lengths (Sn-O bonds within the hexameric cage) cover a range from 2.079(7) to 2.121(7) Å (average 2.102(7) Å), while the Sn-μ2-O bond lengths (related to the bidentate carbonate ions) are slightly longer, ranging from 2.106(7) to 2.167(8) Å (average 2.129(9) Å). The spatial arrangement of the three independent carbonate ions is rather unsymmetric. Those oxygen atoms involved in coordination to the tin atoms show rather long C-O bond lengths, ranging from 1.28(2) to 1.32(2) Å, while the remaining C-O bond lengths are between 1.24(2) and 1.25(1) Å. The latter oxygen atoms are involved in coordination to the potassium ions, whose coordination sphere is completed by five or six water molecules, with K-O distances varying between 2.73(1) and 3.16(1) Å. Overall, the hydrated potassium ions fill the voids between the hexameric methylstannoxyl carbonate ions [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6- in the crystal lattice.

elements.content: Molecular structure of the [MeSn(O)CO3]6 6− ion showing 50% probability ellipsoids and the crystallographic numbering scheme. Selected bond lengths [Å]: Sn1−O1 2.091(8), Sn1−O2 2.110(7), Sn1−O3a 2.110(8), Sn1−O4 2.167(8), Sn1−O5 2.129(6), Sn1−C1 2.11(1), Sn2−O1a 2.093(7), Sn2−O2 2.121(7), Sn2−O3 2.079(7), Sn2−O6 2.106(7), Sn2−O7 2.140(8), Sn2−C2 2.12(1), Sn3−O1 2.111(7), Sn3−O2 2.096(8), Sn3−O3 2.104(7), Sn3−O8 2.107(9), Sn3−O9 2.122(7), Sn3−C3 2.10(1), C10−O5 1.30(1), C10−O7a 1.32(2), C10−O15e 1.25(1), C11c−O4a 1.32(2), C11c−O8a 1.28(2), C11c−O10c 1.24(2), C12b−O6a 1.29(1), C12b−O9a 1.30(1), C12b−O11b 1.24(1).

The 119Sn MAS NMR of the amorphous methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n (1) prepared from 2 by the published procedure shows two signals at δiso = −448 and −470 of approximately the same intensity. Both chemical shifts are indicative for hexacoordinated tin atoms. By contrast, for commercially available butylstannonic acid [BuSn(O)OH] n , 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy revealed approximately 80% hexacoordinated tin and 20% pentacoordinated tin atoms. For the related well-defined dodecanuclear cluster [(BuSn)12O14(OH)6](OH)2·4HOi-Pr 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy independently confirmed the presence of 50% hexacoordinated tin and 50% pentacoordinated tin atoms. While the precise structure of methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n (1) remains elusive, pentacoordinated tins atoms or a local symmetry similar to those of the well-established Sn12 oxo cluster family can be clearly ruled out.
elements.clean_text: The 119Sn MAS NMR of the amorphous methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1) prepared from 2 by the published procedure   shows two signals at δiso = -448 and -470 of approximately the same intensity. Both chemical shifts are indicative for hexacoordinated tin atoms. By contrast, for commercially available butylstannonic acid [BuSn(O)OH] n , 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy revealed approximately 80% hexacoordinated tin and 20% pentacoordinated tin atoms.   For the related well-defined dodecanuclear cluster [(BuSn)12O14(OH)6](OH)2⋅4HOi-Pr 119Sn MAS NMR spectroscopy independently confirmed the presence of 50% hexacoordinated tin and 50% pentacoordinated tin atoms.   While the precise structure of methylstannonic acid [MeSn(O)OH] n  (1) remains elusive, pentacoordinated tins atoms or a local symmetry similar to those of the well-established Sn12 oxo cluster family   can be clearly ruled out.

elements.content: The 13C and 119Sn CP MAS NMR spectra were obtained at 100.53 and 149.25 MHz using a JEOL Eclipse Plus 400 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with a 6 mm rotor operating at spinning frequencies between 8 and 10 kHz. A 5 s recycle delay was used for both nuclei, and typically 5000 to 10 000 transitions were accumulated to obtain sufficient signal-to-noise ratios. Referencing to SiMe4 (13C) and SnMe4 (119Sn) was achieved using crystalline adamantane (δ 38.56/29.50) and c-Hex4Sn (δ −97.35) as secondary references, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State NMR Spectroscopy

The 13C and 119Sn CP MAS NMR spectra were obtained at 100.53 and 149.25 MHz using a JEOL Eclipse Plus 400 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with a 6 mm rotor operating at spinning frequencies between 8 and 10 kHz. A 5 s recycle delay was used for both nuclei, and typically 5000 to 10000 transitions were accumulated to obtain sufficient signal-to-noise ratios. Referencing to SiMe4 (13C) and SnMe4 (119Sn) was achieved using crystalline adamantane (δ 38.56/29.50) and c-Hex4Sn (δ -97.35) as secondary references, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal data and structure solution: C12H46K6O38Sn6, M r = 1745.23, triclinic, P1̅, a = 9.572(2) Å, b = 11.724(2) Å, c = 11.838(2) Å, α = 62.77(1)°, β = 76.19(2)°, γ = 87.759(15)°, V = 1143.4(4) Å3, Z = 1, D x = 2.494 Mg/m3, F(000) = 808, μ = 3.878 mm−1, T = 150 K. Intensity data were collected on a STOE IPDS 2T area detector fitted with Mo Kα radiation (graphite crystal monochromator, λ = 0.71073 Å) to a maximum of θmax = 26.00° via ω scans (completeness 93.9% to θmax). Data were reduced and corrected for absorption with the program STOE X-Area, and the structure was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier synthesis using the program SHELX-97 implemented in the program WinGX 2002. Full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2, using all data, was carried out with anisotropic displacement parameters applied to all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were included in geometrically calculated positions using a riding model (including free rotation about Sn−C) and were refined isotropically. Hydrogen atoms attached to the water molecules were not detected during the refinement and therefore omitted. R 1 = 0.0637 for 4223 [I > 2σ(I)] and wR 2 = 0.1663 for 2961 independent reflections. GooF = 0.995. The max. and min. residual electron densities were 1.923 and −2.739 e Å−3. The figure was prepared using the DIAMOND program. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC no. (2). Copies of this information may be obtained free of charge from The Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

metadata.title:
Hexameric Methylstannoxyl Carbonate Ion [MeSn(O)CO3]6
6−. A Missing Link with a Drum-Type Structure
